Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 09:01AM Kadia wrote: Trazodone is actually in an entirely different class of drug from Restoril, Lunesta, and Ambien. It is not a benzodiazapine but an antidepressant. AFAIK, people do not develop tolerance to trazodone, nor is it habit forming, so it is safe for long term use.
Posts.Title: 6 month call back/also trazodone question gail_p-m Kadia

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2012 10:32AM Kadia wrote: I have taken trazodone for insomnia for about a year pre-dx, and my onc did not say it was contraindictated.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2012 03:46PM Kadia wrote: I had been running for about 8 months when my BC adventure started. Was up to 8 miles running and had done a half marathon alternating running and walking. Just today, I tried my first run in 3 months. It was terrible at first, largely due to shin splints. I walked for a while, then was able to run a little over a mile without pain. I was slower than before, but definitely not totally back to square 1. I am currently in the middle of chemo, so think it will be a bit easier once I am through with it. Really, the only place we can start is where we are...
Posts.Title: Athletes, how fast will stamina come back? drwendy sanbar8771

Posts.Content: Kadia wrote: "Chemo Brain" is definitely real...I know because I forgot to refrigerate my Neupogen, as directed. I only realized after I had given myself all 5 days of injections, which I stored at room temperature. Anyone know the possible consequences of having injected room-temperature Neupogen? I am hoping the answer is that the medicine is less effective...not that it becomes some contaminated soup. For the record, I am not experiencing side effects any different than my previous round of chemo (T/C), when I did not have Neupogen at all. Right now, I am feeling too embarassed to call and ask my MO about this. Thought I would at least start here and see if anyone on BCO knows what happens to Neupogen that is not refrigerated...  Multicentric/multifocal IDC & DCIS; Lumpectomy 12-11; UMX with immediate recon (TEs) 1-12; chemo began 2-12 (TCx4); Tamoxifen 5 years starting ?? Dx 10/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Kadia wrote: I have a dilemma and am trying to figure out what to do. I had a UMX in mid-January. Haven't seen my MO yet, but my BS said that chemo is likely to be recommended to me due to my tumors being multifocal and multicentric and also my (relatively) young age. No oncotype score yet. I am ER/PR+, HER2 -, with a very low (5%) Ki-67 score. My issue is that I have a very big trip--my 20th college reunion--coming up in early June, and have been planning to attend with friends since before my dx. The reunion is across the country from where I live and is in a big, busy city.  If I can do so safely, I really want to put off chemo until early June, which would be about 19 weeks post-surgery. From reading here, it seems that the standard of care is to begin chemo no later than 12 weeks post-surgery.  I am wondering: 1) how long most people go between surgery and chemo   2) where that 12 week standard comes from  3) If I do begin chemo before June, should I assume a cross-country trip to a big city is a no-go if it falls mid-treatment? Thanks so much for sharing your perspectives!  Multicentric/multifocal IDC & DCIS; Lumpectomy 12-11; UMX with immediate recon (TEs) 1-12; chemo began 2-12 (TCx4); Tamoxifen 5 years starting ?? Dx 10/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 12:32PM Kadia wrote: I second the recommendation for Lands End. Their mastectomy suits are really great (I have TEs but am still very lopsided, so put a prosthesis in one of the pockets). They are well made, have higher armholes, padded tops...I love them. Also, if you have a Sears near you, you can return Land's End items there.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 12:02PM Kadia wrote: Weight gain is indeed a common side effect from antidepressants. Wellbutrin is supposed to be weight-neutral, but does work differently (wasn't effective for me at all). It can be harder to lose weight while on SSRIs, but it can be done.

Posts.Content: Kadia wrote: This may be a stupid question, but I am concerned. I am 3 weeks post-UMX and 2 months post-sentinel node biopsy, and seem to have either swelling or prominent tissue on the outside of the removed breast and below the underarm where the nodes were removed. How would I know the difference between swollen/prominent tissue and lymphedema? I assume lymphedema can present in areas other than the arm or hand (was reading another thread here about breast lymphedema, which made me wonder if that was what was happening to me). The swollen looking areas are not painful, but they are noticeably larger and "puffier" than on my other (non-MX) side. Can lymphedema present without pain or even discomfort?
